title: Granddad, 75, breaks both arms on Mauritius holiday then dies on journey home
text:

A grandfather broke both his arms on holiday, then tragically died on the journey home.

Louis 'Reg' Belcourt fell on May 28 this year shortly after arriving in Mauritius.

The 75-year-old was taken to a local clinic and treated for the double arm break, Kent Live reported.

On June 1 he had a second surgery on his shoulders which led to him developing complications.

Three days later his stepdaughter Sephanie Belcourt spoke to him on the phone and realised he was suffering from post-op delerium.

Mr Belcourt, who was well known in Hythe, Kent as a former town councillor, took a turn for the worse when breathing problems put him on a ventilator.

(Image: Getty Images)

An intubation tube was also placed into his windpipe to keep his airways open.

Realising his condition was increasingly serious, family members flew out to be with the pensioner and began work on having him repatriated.

The process was slow and disrupted by a last minute change that required them to board a different plane.

Mr Belcourt was finally flown out of the country on June 15 amidst fears from doctors at the Mauritius hospital that prolonged intubation could lead to infections or complications.

“They said the longer he was left there, the more liable he is for infection," Ms Belcourt told an inquest at Archbishop's Place in Maidstone, Kent.

She added: “What they feared would happen did happen.”

As the plane descended towards its planned stopover destination of Nuremberg, Mr Belcourt began to experience breathing difficulties.

His tidal volume - the amount of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation - was plummeting.

(Image: KentLive/ WS)

Those by Mr Belcourt's side sprung into action and started trying to resuscitate him while the plane neared the runway.

An ambulance and paramedics were waiting for him on the tarmac when the plane came to a halt.

Further attempts to resuscitate him proved unsuccessful however, and Mr Belcourt was declared dead.

A post-mortem examination found the cause of death to be cardiomegaly - an abnormal enlargement of the heart which may have prevented it from pumping properly - and sepsis.

The fractures he sustained and the subsequent ventilation were recorded as a secondary cause of death.

Assistant Coroner Jill Wood said: “He died as a consequence of prolonged ventilation following surgery for fractures from a fall.”

During the October 23 inquest the court also heard that Mr Belcourt was also a skilled mariner and had been a sea captain.

He was married to Keren Belcourt, a councillor who also served as Hythe mayor. She died in 2014.

They had five children and thirteen grand-children between them.
description: Louis Belcourt from Hythe, Kent slipped and broke his arms while on holiday on the Indian Ocean island
